title: Get ready for Brexit (but you can never, ever travel)
text:
Welcome to Declassified, a new weekly column looking at the lighter side of politics. You can find it in POLITICO's weekly print edition and online on Fridays.

READY, STEADY, OH!

“Get ready,” sang The Temptations in one of the most life-affirming pieces of music ever recorded. “Get ready,” said the British government as it unveiled its no-deal Brexit preparations, to the sound of audible groaning.

Yes, the £100 million public information campaign urging people to make sure they are prepared for Britain’s departure from the EU has finally been launched. There are adverts to run on TV, radio, social media and billboards, but most importantly a website full of handy advice and a questionnaire.

If, for the sake of argument, you were a British citizen living in another EU country, question 5 is this: “Do you plan to travel after 31 October 2019?” Not ‘do you plan to travel just after 31 October 2019?’ or ‘do you have travel booked?” But do you ever want to travel again! Is it a trap to flush out Remainers who enjoy going to exotic places with their spicy food and, well, foreigners?

The landing page of the same site features the bold statement “The UK will leave the EU on 31 October 2019.” That’s very much in keeping with Boris Johnson’s line since he became PM. But it’s a high-risk game that the cosplay Donald Trump is playing and if it fails he could go down in the record books as the PM with the shortest tenure in British history.

George Canning holds that record. He was PM for 119 days (if you’re prime minister in Italy for 119 days you get a statue and a public holiday named after you). Johnson took office on July 24, so will pass Canning’s mark on November 20. If he survives that long, Johnson will need a new prime ministerial role model, and there’s only one candidate. No, not Churchill, but Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman. He was the first man to be given official use of the title Prime Minister and once said “I am an immense believer in bed, in constantly keeping horizontal ... The heart and everything else go slower, and the whole system is refreshed.” He died after a series of heart attacks.

DOS AND DON'TS

DON’T: Bother with Mike Pence

Say what you like about Donald Trump (no, really, say what you like) but at least he’s interesting. So imagine booking Trump and getting Mike Pence, as happened to the poor Poles at the weekend. It’s like having a ticket to see Iggy Pop and getting Mumford & Sons. At least Poland has so few high-ranking female politicians it couldn’t cause the famously women-averse Pence any embarrassment.

DON’T: Slouch

Man of the people and Leader of the House Jacob Rees-Mogg was a walking, talking, lying down ad for voting against the government Tuesday. As well as being photographed virtually horizontal on the front bench of the Commons, he also said the plan to stop a no-deal Brexit is “the most unconstitutional use of this house since the days of Charles Stewart Parnell.” That resulted in the bizarre sight of a member of parliament from 1875 to 1891 trending on Twitter — and not just Rees-Mogg!

DON’T: Call the mayor of London sadistic

From the man who gave us the “Prince of Whales” comes “Sadique Kahn.” Yes, Donald Trump, sworn enemy of the English language, was at it again, royally mucking up the mayor’s name and inadvertently using the French word for sadist and the German word for boat.

CAPTION COMPETITION

Paul Dallison is POLITICO's Slot News Editor
description: The UK’s new website on leaving the EU contains a surprising question.
